questions.text: All of the following can lead to increase in venous pressure except:
questions.solution:
Spinal cord injury leads to a distributive type of shock in which venous pressure would be low.

Myocardial infarction can produce cardiogenic shock in which venous pressure would be high.

Cardiac tamponade and air emboli can produce an obstructive type of shock in which venous pressure would be high.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter: 2, 28th Edition, Page Number- 12.

questions.text: All of the following will produce distributive type of shock except:
questions.solution:
Thyrotoxicosis is type of endocrine shock.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 2, Edition: 28th, Pg: 12

questions.text:
Rasiklal 55 years old male patient who is asthmatic, undergone laparotomy for intestinal obstruction,on postoperative day 3 his Blood pressure was 90/60, Pulse was 110/min, urine output was adequate, passed stool 4 times and peripheries found warm. Surgeon orders ABGA report and found to be as follows:
pH=7.35, PaO2=76mmHg, mixed venous saturation = 75%, base deficit found high
what can be the cause for this:
questions.solution:
Option A: Here patient found to be in shock his blood pressure and pulse were altered. Periphery of patient found to be WARM and other aspects which suggest this could be septic shock are:Mixed venous oxygen saturation was 75% Base deficit high.

Option B: Arrythmia can produce cardiogenic shock but in it, peripheries would; be cold and mixed venous oxygen saturation would be low

Option C: Tension pneumothorax produce obstructive shock but again in it, Mixed venous oxygen saturation would be low and peripheries would be low and chances of tension pneumothorax would be low as there is no any other complication occur.

Option D: Diarrhea would lead to hypovolemic shock but in it, peripheries would be cold and mixed venous oxygen saturation would be low.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 2, Edition: 28th, Pg: 14

questions.text:
Mathew undergo an accident and admitted in casualty with bleeding from extremity Bleeding stopped with pressure pack. His parameters are as follows:
Pulse - 96/min
Blood pressure- 110/80 mmHg
He is found well oriented to time, place and person.
Blood loss was approximately 500 ml.
What is class of hemorrhage for this patient:
questions.solution: Reference: Schwartz Principles of surgery, chapter: 5, Edition: 11th, Pg: 142

questions.text: Blood loss of 1250 ml included in which class of hemorrhage:
questions.solution:
750-1500 ml blood loss included in II class of Hemorrhage.

Classification of hemorrhagic shocks:

  • <750 ml loss is class 1
  • 75—1500 ml loss is class 2
  • 1500-2000 ml loss is class 3
  • >2000 ml is class 4 shock

Reference: Schwartz Principles of surgery; chapter: 5; Edition: 11th; Pg: 142

questions.text: Multiple organ failure is defined as failure of how many organs?
questions.solution:
Multiple organ failure is defined as 2 or more failed organ system.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 2, Edition: 28th, Pg: 13

choices.text: In patient with active bleeding due to major trauma first step should be controlling Bleeding rather than starting high fluid therapy.
In patient with Bowel obstruction first step should be to resuscitate a patient
In patient with active bleeding due to major trauma first step always be fluid therapy.
Airway and breathing must be ensured in every patient presenting with shock.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true except:
questions.solution:
In patients who are actively bleeding (major trauma, aortic aneurysm rupture, gastrointestinal hemorrhage), it is counterproductive to institute high-volume fluid therapy without controlling the site of hemorrhage.

Increasing blood pressure merely increases bleeding from the site while fluid therapy cools the patient and dilutes available coagulation factors. Thus operative hemorrhage control should not be delayed and resuscitation should proceed in parallel with surgery.

Conversely, a patient with bowel obstruction and hypovolemic shock must be adequately resuscitated before undergoing surgery otherwise the additional surgical injury and hypovolemia induced during the procedure will exacerbate the inflammatory activation and increase the incidence and severity of end-organ insult.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 2, Edition: 28th

choices.text: First line therapy is putting a short wide bore intravenous cannula and start Infusion.
Albumin should not be the start in immediate period
Ringer lactate is most physiological fluid and ideal crystalloid.
It is ideal to give inotropic agents regardless of preload to heart.

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding fluid therapy for shock.
questions.solution:
If inotropic agents given before achieving adequate preload it will deplete myocardium of oxygen stores and decrease coronary perfusion, so this should not be first priority.

  • In early period of shock vascular permeability would be high so albumin Will not stand in vascular system and start to accumulate in interstitial space.
  • Ringer lactate is ideal physiological fluid as it has all contents required For plasma.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 2, Edition: 28th, Pg: 18

questions.text: All of the following fluids are isotonic in body except:
questions.solution:
Please remember that 5%dextrose in water is isotonic when it is in pint form but when administered in body, Dextrose will rapidly utilize and then it will act as hypotonic fluid.

  • So, if asked without mentioning in body go with 5% Dextrose as isotonic Fluid.
  • Ringer solution is similar to Ringer lactate, but it has no lactate as content.

    • Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of surgery 28th edition Chapter 2, page no 18

questions.text:
Mr. Y (45 years old) suffered an accident and admitted in casualty. His parameters are as follows:
He is drowsy and not oriented to time and person.
Pulse- 130/min
Blood pressure- 90/62 mmHg
Respiratory rate- 32/min
Urine output- 15ml/hour
What would be grade of shock according these parameters?
questions.solution:
Remember that urine output, blood pressure altered in moderate severity of shock.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 2, Edition: 28th, Pg: 14

questions.text: In case of blood loss, ideal replacement fluid is?
questions.solution:
In case of blood loss, blood products are the ideal replacement fluids as crystalloids and colloids have no oxygen carrying capacity and also don't contain coagulation factors, RBCs etc.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 2, Edition: 28th, Pg: 21

questions.text: Mr. X has been admitted in casualty and his parameters were P-102/min,BP- 90/64 mmHg and urine output- 20ml/hour. He has been given 250 ml of ringer lactate. Following this his parameters were P-98/min, BP-98/68 mmHg and urine Output- 30ml/hour. But again in half an hour parameters shift to previous one This would categorize patient as?
questions.solution:
Here patient's parameters improved after giving fluid but again became as previous one that suggest patient is Transient responder and have moderate ongoing fluid loss.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 2, Edition: 28th, Pg: 15

questions.text: In case of shock amount of bolus of fluid required to see response would be?
questions.solution:
250 to 500 ml of fluid should be given as bolus to see dynamic response.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 2, Edition: 28th, Pg: 18

questions.text: Vasopressor agents are ideal in which type of shock:
questions.solution:
• Vasopressor agents (phenylephrine, noradrenaline) are indicated in distributive shock states (sepsis, neurogenic shock) where there is peripheral vasodilatation, and a low systemic vascular resistance, leading to hypotension despite a high cardiac output.
  • In thyrotoxicosis there would be already heart is overacting and vasopressor given without correcting preload it will produce detrimental effects to myocardium.

    • Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 2, Edition: 28th, Pg: 18

questions.text: Which marker is best measure of organ perfusion?
questions.solution:
Urine output is ideal indicator to measure organ perfusion and to monitor adequacy of fluid therapy.

CVP is ideal to measure response to fluid therapy but it is not ideal to Measure organ perfusion

Base deficit and lactate level are also good indicators but they are more Invasive and not rapidly available in all places.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 2, Edition: 28th, Pg: 19

questions.text: All of the following investigation is done to monitor gut perfusion except:
questions.solution:
Near infrared spectroscopy is used to measure perfusion to Muscle and Brain.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 2, Edition: 28th, Pg: 19

choices.text: It suggests oxygen delivery and extraction by tissue and its normal levels are 50-70%
In Hypovolemic shock it can be below 50%
In septic shock its should always be maintained below 70%
Sample taken from Rt atrium and other veins slightly differs.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding mixed venous oxygen saturation except:
questions.solution:
Mixed venous oxygen saturation suggests oxygen delivery to tissue and its Extraction by tissue. Its normal levels are 50-70%.

  • level below 50% is consistent with Hypovolemic or cardiogenic shock
  • In septic shock and other distributive type of shock its level is >70%
  • Patients who are septic should have mixed venous oxygen saturations above 70%; below this level, they are not only in septic shock but also in hypovolemic or cardiogenic shock. Although the SvO2 level is in the 'normal' range, it is low for the septic state, and inadequate oxygen is being supplied to cells that cannot utilize oxygen appropriately
  • This must be corrected rapidly. Hypovolemia should be corrected with fluid therapy, and low cardiac output due to myocardial depression or failure should be treated with inotropes(dobutamine), to achieve a mixed venous saturation greater than 70% (normal for the septic state).

    • Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 2, Edition: 28th, Pg: 19

questions.text: If Mr. Z has heart rate of 105/min, systolic blood pressure= 90 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure=60 mmHg. What would be Modified shock index for these parameters?
questions.solution: Reference: Schwartz Principles of surgery, chapter: 5, Edition: 11th, Pg: 161

questions.text: Mrs. Patel undergone thyroidectomy and in 12 hours of surgery suture site appear bulging, Surgeon immediately open the suture site and evacuate hematoma ,he found dislodgement of suture at superior pedicle. What kind of hemorrhage is this?
questions.solution:
Reactionary hemorrhage is delayed hemorrhage (within 24 hours) and is usually due to dislodgement of a clot by resuscitation, normalization of blood pressure and vasodilatation. Reactionary hemorrhage may also be due to technical failure, such as slippage of a ligature.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 2, Edition: 28th, Pg: 15

questions.text: Hemorrhage occurring after 7 days due to sloughing of wall of vessel categorized into:
questions.solution:
Option A: Primary hemorrhage is hemorrhage occurring immediately due to an injury (or surgery).

Option B: Secondary hemorrhage is due to sloughing of the wall of a vessel. It usually occurs 7-14 days after injury and is precipitated by factors such as infection, pressure necrosis (such as from a drain) or malignancy.

Option D: Reactionary hemorrhage is delayed hemorrhage (within 24 hours) and is usually due to dislodgement of a clot by resuscitation, normalization of blood pressure and vasodilatation. Reactionary hemorrhage may also be due to technical failure, such as slippage of a ligature.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 2, Edition: 28th, Pg: 15

questions.text: All of the following strategies done for Damage control resuscitation except:
questions.solution:
The four central strategies of DCR are:

  1. Anticipate and treat acute traumatic coagulopathy.
  2. Permissive hypotension until hemorrhage control.
  3. Limit crystalloid and colloid infusion to avoid dilutional coagulopathy.
  4. Damage control surgery to control hemorrhage and preserve physiology.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 2, Edition: 28th, Pg: 16-17

questions.text: Which of the following is more sensitive and accurate test to measure coagulation changes in surgical patients?
questions.solution: Reference: Schwartz Principles of surgery, chapter: 5, Edition: 11th, Pg: 145

questions.text: All of the followings are contents of lethal triad except:
questions.solution:
Lethal triad includes -

Acidosis

Hypothermia

Coagulopathy

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition, Chapter 4 page no 53

questions.text:
Mr. N was involved in a car accident and was admitted in the casualty with extremity bleeding. His parameters are as follows:
He is confused and not oriented properly.
Pulse-126/min
Blood pressure-88/60 mmHg
Urine output- 15 ml/hour
Respiratory rate- 34/min
Identify the correct option for this patient from the following.
questions.solution:
In Class III, there would be hypotension due to blood loss so ideal fluid would be crystalloid and blood.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page Number-50.

questions.text: Blood pressure will start to fall after how much blood loss occurs:
questions.solution:
Blood pressure falls in Class 3 hemorrhagic shock, Blood lost is around 30-40%.

Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of surgery 28th edition, chapter 2, page no 15

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for reperfusion injury?
questions.solution:
Reperfusion injury is mainly because of Hyperkalemia

Acid and Potassium load that has built up due to hypoperfusion diverted to heart and other organs once perfusion restored and this leads to myocardial depression, vascular dilation and further hypotension.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 2, Edition: 28th, Pg: 11
